title: Dominion is currently balanced better than Summoner's Rift
body:
Prove me wrong.

Edit:

I didn't expect this thread to be as popular as it is, so I just want to say a few quick things.

I do not claim Dominion to be the pinnacle of balanced game modes, it definitely has its fair share of flaws and overpowered champions. This thread was intended to highlight Riot's sheer lack of competence when it comes to balancing League, and managing it altogether also. 

Cheers.

replies.body:
Well, lets see...

Summoner's Rift:  Massively tilted in favor of early game champions.
Crystal Scar:  Both early stomp to win comps and stall for late game comps work equally well.

Summoner's Rift:  Fairly ridged lane positions that restrict team compositions.
Crystal Scar:  Provided you have one champ who can hold bottom lane, ideal team compositions are based purely on champion synergy and counter-picks.

Summoner's Rift:  Massive collection of champions who are absolute trash.
Crystal Scar:  The only bad champions are the ones with stacking mechanics that aren't adjusted for the lack of lane phase and/or shorter games.

Summoner's Rift:  Objectives favor Marksmen and require at least one on each team.
Crystal Scar:  Objectives can be taken with equal ease by all champions, making Marksmen optional.

Summoner's Rift:  Snowballs like crazy, leading to a toxic defeatist attitude.  Many games end in surrender.
Crystal Scar:  What little snowballing exists is countered by respawn timers and team bounties.  The game is never over until its over.

Summoner's Rift:  Lane phase combined with snowballing means one guy can totally lose the game for you 15 minutes in, leading to toxic team-mate blaming.
Crystal Scar:  A team game right from the gate, encourages team cooperation.

Looks like it checks out.

Just as an example, champions with no ultimates or very short CD ults greatly outclass champions with big long CD ults as fighting happens all the time instead of once every 3-5 minutes. Global or semi-global teleports on reasonable CDs(Pantheon, TF) are also extremely strong, as is hypermobility(Riven, Nidalee, Quinn).

CHEESECAKE ALL OVER THE CEILING!!!

The dominion community simply can't stress the strategic limits of dominion nearly as well as the SR community can, so you're going to see fairly lax metagames, like the one IPU speaks of, where things appear balanced because the small imbalances aren't being constantly and consistently exploited, or because larger imbalances are simply being overlooked.

Hypermobility only matters if you have to run, because objectives can be easily capped when they aren't present and teamfighting starts as soon as the game does. 

The only champions that are trash are the ones reliant on hyper-scaling or traps because the games are shorter and the map so much more open.

The only meta is that at the start of the game, one goes bot while another captures the side and the rest go top. Even back when they did pseudo-competitive Dominion matches, the pick/bans weren't considered unhealthy (Except for Kassadin and Nidalee, who were notorious offenders back in the day) because you could just as easily counter them with anything you wanted.

ADC - no-farm Support was specifically what supplanted the Roam meta because regardless of who you stuck in bottom lane they got pimp-slapped by the Corki/Janna duo or whoever you felt like fielding down there. Dominion doesn't have that issue because it has two lane positions, not five.  Bottom and everyone else.

Well and fine if its just faulty memory.  I have a thing about spreading misinformation.  Suffice to say, this wasn't a thing that popped up from EU.  In fact, in a thread that popped up on the old boards while Support/ADC was really cementing itself a Rioter dropped in to mention that they had been running comps like that in their internal play tests for the past several months.

Doubt I could find the thread again, but I figure if Riot's handful of testers were able to find the optimal lane positions despite being a pretty small group of folks then the Dominion player base, which is comparatively larger, should be able to do just fine.
 
> This isn't true. It's completely possible for an optimal team comp to emerge that simply has no counter. One may not exist right now, but with balance changes one may in the future. There's nothing inherently stopping it from happening.

This is possible.  It is also possible that the universe is in fact made of chocolate pudding and our senses are lying to us.  Simply because there exists some chance that a thing may be does not mean that a thing is.  Given how many moving parts League has, I strongly doubt there's such a thing as an unbeatable team comp.

> I don't know about this. Any of the current widely-used archetypes, sure. But most archetypes are somewhat (if not completely) subjective. And it's clear that the objectives favour some champions, for example, defending a point is much easier as Kog'Maw than as Tryndamere. 

Taking objectives is champion neutral.  But some champions are certainly better at defending points than others.  Of course, defending a point isn't always the best plan.  Sometimes you're better off falling back and finding somewhere else to attack.

> Snowballing isn't inherently bad.

Sure.  Some games snowball (Chess) others do not (Baseball).  But in a game like League, snowballing is the direct cause of quite a bit of toxic player behavior.  It also obscures the raw mechanical strength of champions.  Because players in Dominion are on more or less equal footing, it is much easier to get a feel for relative champion power.

> Sure. But unless champions are balanced EXTREMELY well, which I highly doubt, there's going to be an optimal set of them that outclass others to some degree. Maybe not in every way, or in every possible teamcomp imaginable, but there are champs that are better than others. There are also teamcomps that are better than others (maybe not in specific this-vs-that comp matchups, but better as in easier to pick into, harder to counter effectively, etc).

I *will* agree with this statement, however.  Some champions *are stronger* than others on Dominion.  But that's true regardless of what map you're talking about.

To be fair dominion was always closer to balanced than the boards and developers believed it to be, enforced scaling will do that.  Nine tenths of SRs balancing problems are because of gold and level scaling, and scaling of exposure to allies and teammates.  Two problems Dominion doesn't have since there is no way to outfarm the passive gold and experience gain, and both grouping up and splitting are done in response to enemy and ally action instead of whether or not you have farming to do or passively spawning objectives to contest.

Dominion's current balance issues are more related to items than champions. I see two obvious issues: Poor anti-stealth items (which, granted, is more frustrating than it is unbalancing) and poor marksmen items (which mostly makes a class of champion a bit undertuned but still viable).

Dominion is fairly balanced right now. I'd like to see some small item changes (better anti-stealth itemization and better ADC items), but aside from that there's not that much that needs to be done.
